description: Erection of detached garden room to rear of property (following removal of existing timber building)
decision_conditions: The development hereby permitted shall begin before the expiration of three years from the date of this permission.	Reason:  As required  by Section 91 of  the Town  and Country Planning  Act  1990,  as amended by Section 51 of the Planning and Compulsory Purchase Act 2004.

Development  shall  be  carried  out  in  accordance  with  the  materials  specified  on  the approved plans and on the application form unless otherwise agreed in writing by the Local Planning Authority.	Reason: To ensure a satisfactory appearance on completion of the development in accordance with Policy DM10 (Design Requirements for New Developments including House Extensions) of the LDF Core Strategy Adopted April 2012.

The outbuilding hereby permitted shall only be used as ancillary to the main house and shall not be converted into a separate dwelling without the grant of further specific planning permission from the Local Planning Authority.Reason: To safeguard the primary use on the site and to prevent the intensification of the site.

The proposed roof of the outbuilding hereby permitted shall not be converted or used as a balcony or a sitting out area, and no access shall be gained except for maintenance purposes. 	Reason: To protect the amenities and privacy of the adjoining properties in accordance with Policy DM10 (Design Requirements for New Developments including House Extensions) of the LDF Core Strategy Adopted April 2012.

The site comprises a semi-detached property which has been divided into flat and contains a hairdressers on the ground floor with a flat to the rear.The key areas of assessment are:- The design of the proposed development; and,- The impact of the development on the amenities of existing and future occupants of land and buildings.When read together Policies CS8 and DM10 of the Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames Local Development Framework Core Strategy (CS)(2012) and the guidance in the Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames Residential Design Guide SPD (2013) require proposals to be of a high quality design that respects the character and appearance of the original building and the prevailing character of the surrounding area. Officer Comment: Officers acknowledge a 6m extension has been permitted and built at adjoining propoerty No. 155 Kingston Road. In this case the proposed extension measuring 5 metres in depth would not be unusual in its context and would not appear overly domiant or disproportionate. Therefore, the proposed development is considered to be acceptable in terms of scale, form, bulk, height, massing, spacing and design. It is considered that there would be no adverse impacts on the character or appearance of the area as a result of the proposed development.Policy DM10 of the Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames Local Development Framework Core Strategy (CS)(2012) and the guidance in the Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames Residential Design Guide SPD (2013) requires proposal to have regard to the amenities of the future occupants of the development as well as those of the existing occupants of neighbouring land and buildings, including in terms of privacy, outlook, sunlight/daylight, avoidance of visual intrusion and noise and disturbance.Officer Comment:  It is considered that the proposed development would not adversely affect the amenities of the occupiers of neighbouring properties by reason of overbearing appearance, loss of light or loss of privacy.In conclusion, the proposed development would accord with the National Planning Policy Framework (2019), the National Planning Practice Guidance, the London Plan (2016) Policies CS8 and DM10 of the Core Strategy (2012) and the Residential Design SPD (2013).

Conditions A.3 (a) states: the materials used in any exterior work (other than materials used in the construction of a conservatory) must be of a similar appearance to those used in the construction of the exterior of the existing dwellinghouse. The proposed use of render would not match the red brick of the existing house.
The proposed amendment to the roof (the total height would be increased by approx. 1m) is a significant change that is not considered to constitute a minor non material change.

The site comprises a block of flats and two houses. The proposed window and door replacements relates to the flats at Nos 1-6 Vineyard Close only. The key areas of assessment are:- The design of the proposed development; and,- The impact of the proposal on the amenities of neighbouring occupiers.When read together Policies CS8 and DM10 of the Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames Local Development Framework Core Strategy (CS)(2012) and the guidance in the Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames Residential Design Guide SPD (2013) require proposals to be of a high quality design that respects the character and appearance of the original building and the prevailing character of the surrounding area. Officer Comment: The proposed UPVC window frames and doors would be of similar appearance, colour and size to the existing windows and would be located in existing aperatures. As such, it is considered that the windows and doors would not result in any material change to the appearance of the building and would not result in any harm to the street scene or character of the area. Policy DM10 of the Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames Local Development Framework Core Strategy (CS)(2012) and the guidance in the Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames Residential Design Guide SPD (2013) requires proposal to have regard to the amenities of the future occupants of the development as well as those of the existing occupants of neighbouring land and buildings, including in terms of privacy, outlook, sunlight/daylight, avoidance of visual intrusion and noise and disturbance.Officer Comment:  It is considered that the proposed development would not adversely affect the amenities of the occupiers of neighbouring properties by reason of loss of privacy.In conclusion, the proposed development would accord with the National Planning Policy Framework (2019), the National Planning Practice Guidance, the London Plan (2016) Policies CS8 and DM10 of the Core Strategy (2012) and the Residential Design SPD (2013).

Please confirm new description of works as the application form description does not correspond with the proposed works in the plans and/or supporting documents.  Confirmation can be in writing or by amending the plans to reflect the proposals.Note: Any documentation with the incorrect proposals will need to be resubmitted, this includes the description of works section on the application form.

Land Reqistry Map provided is not acceptable due to copyrightPlease submit a copy of an Ordnance Survey based site location plan scaled 1:1250 with the application site outlined in red and adjoining land owned by applicant in blue, showing at least two road frontages and a North point.
Please provide details of the proposed materials, and when able to do so, provide actual materials during the course of the determination of your application

As per our previous notification, kindly note that only one 'free-go' application is permitted per applicant, per property. There is no entitlement each time one application is paid for and then another is submitted. Once a 'free-go' has been used (as has been in this case) there is not an entitlement to anotherYour client has previously benefitted from a 'free-go' application, relating to planning permission ref: 09/12091/FUL
